message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: DiffScene: Diffusion-Based Safety-Critical Scenario Generation for Autonomous Vehicles
Paper Abstract: The field of Autonomous Driving (AD) has witnessed significant progress in recent years. Among the various challenges faced, the safety evaluation of autonomous vehicles (AVs) stands out as a critical concern. Traditional evaluation methods are both costly and inefficient, often requiring extensive driving mileage in order to encounter rare safety-critical scenarios, which are distributed on the long tail of the complex real-world driving landscape. In this paper, we propose a unified approach, Diffusion-Based Safety-Critical Scenario Generation (DiffScene), to generate high-quality safety-critical scenarios which are both realistic and safety-critical for efficient AV evaluation. In particular, we propose a diffusion-based generation framework, leveraging the power of approximating the distribution of low-density spaces for diffusion models. We design several adversarial optimization objectives to guide the diffusion generation under predefined adversarial budgets. These objectives, such as safety-based objective, functionality-based objective, and constraint-based objective, ensure the generation of safety-critical scenarios while adhering to specific constraints. Extensive experimentation has been conducted to validate the efficacy of our approach. Compared with 6 SOTA baselines, DiffScene generates scenarios that are (1) more safety-critical under 3 metrics, (2) more realistic under 5 distance functions, and (3) more transferable to different AV algorithms. In addition, we demonstrate that training AV algorithms with scenarios generated by DiffScene leads to significantly higher performance in terms of the safety-critical metrics compared to baselines. These findings highlight the potential of DiffScene in addressing the challenges of AV safety evaluation, paving the way for safer AV development.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Web search results for query: "Scenario generation"

Links: [{"title":"Electric energy consumption - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electric_energy_consumption"},{"title":"Scenario planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scenario_planning"},{"title":"Heroes of Olympus (role-playing game) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heroes_of_Olympus_(role-playing_game)"},{"title":"Bipartite dimension - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bipartite_dimension"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about scenario generation:

## Overview

Scenario planning, scenario thinking, scenario analysis, scenario prediction and the scenario method all describe a strategic planning method that some organizations use to make flexible long-term plans.(no content)It is in large part an adaptation and generalization of classic methods used by military intelligence.

## Key Components

In the most common application of the method, analysts generate simulation games for policy makers.(no content)The method combines known facts, such as demographics, geography and mineral reserves, with military, political, and industrial information, and key driving forces identified by considering social, technical, economic, environmental, and political ("STEEP") trends.

## Purpose and Benefits

I've completed the web search for "Autonomous driving." Here are the key findings:

## Definition and Overview
A self-driving car, also known as an autonomous car, is a car that is capable of operating with reduced or no human input.

## Levels of Automation
SAE identified 6 levels for driving automation from level 0 to level 5. These range from:
- Level 1: Driver assistance, where the vehicle controls steering or speed autonomously in specific circumstances
- Level 5: Full autonomy, where the vehicle can complete travel autonomously in any environmental conditions

## Recent Commercial Development
Waymo, an American autonomous driving technology company, operates commercial robotaxi services available to the public in Phoenix, the San Francisco Bay Area, Los Angeles, Atlanta, and Austin.(no content)As of December 2025, it operates over 450,000 rides per week.

## Key Companies and Technology
Tesla Autopilot is an advanced driver-assistance system that provides partial vehicle automation, corresponding to Level 2 automation.(no content)Wayve Technologies is a British autonomous driving technology company focused on developing self-driving vehicle systems through end-to-end deep learning, founded in 2017 by researchers from the University of Cambridge.

## Regulatory Status
As of December 2024, about half the US states had statutes regulating vehicles operated by some degree of autonomous technology.

Web search results for query: "Adversarial optimization"

Links: [{"title":"Adversarial machine learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adversarial_machine_learning"},{"title":"Generative adversarial network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Generative_adversarial_network"},{"title":"Mode collapse - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mode_collapse"},{"title":"Computationally bounded adversary - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computationally_bounded_adversary"},{"title":"Adversary model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adversary_model"},{"title":"Search algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adversarial_search"},{"title":"Robust optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robust_optimization"},{"title":"Ant colony optimization algorithms - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ant_colony_optimization_algorithms"},{"title":"Network Coordinate System - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_Coordinate_System"},{"title":"Advantage (cryptography) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Advantage_(cryptography)"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about adversarial optimization:

## Overview

Adversarial optimization casts optimization into a game, with a minimax structure that is different from the usual kind of optimization. This approach has become particularly prominent in machine learning.

## Key Applications

**Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs):** One of the most well-known applications of adversarial optimization is GANs, which address optimization problems previously plagued with "intractable probabilistic computations that arise in maximum likelihood estimation". In GANs, the generator moves first and the discriminator moves second, creating a minimax game structure.

**Adversarial Machine Learning Security:** Optimization-based attacks such as GAMMA use genetic algorithms to frame evasion as a constrained optimization problem that balances misclassification success with the size of the injected payload.

**Control Theory:** In control theory, adversarial learning based on neural networks was used in 2006 to train robust controllers in a game theoretic sense, by alternating iterations between a minimizer policy (the controller) and a maximizer policy (the disturbance).

## Related Concepts

Adversarial optimization is closely related to robust optimization, which deals with optimization problems in which a certain measure of robustness is sought against uncertainty.

Web search results for query: "Diffusion model"

Links: [{"title":"Diffusion model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diffusion_model"},{"title":"Bass diffusion model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bass_diffusion_model"},{"title":"Latent diffusion model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latent_diffusion_model"},{"title":"Stable Diffusion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stable_Diffusion"},{"title":"Text-to-image model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Text-to-image_model"},{"title":"Demic diffusion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Demic_diffusion"},{"title":"NovelAI - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NovelAI"},{"title":"Foundation model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Foundation_model"},{"title":"DALL-E - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DALL-E"},{"title":"Midjourney - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Midjourney"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about diffusion models:

## Overview

In machine learning, diffusion models, also known as diffusion-based generative models or score-based generative models, are a class of latent variable generative models.(no content)A diffusion model models data as generated by a diffusion process, whereby a new datum performs a random walk with drift through the space of all possible data.

## How They Work

A diffusion model consists of two major components: the forward diffusion process, and the reverse sampling process.(no content)The goal of diffusion models is to learn a diffusion process for a given dataset, such that the process can generate new elements that are distributed similarly as the original dataset.

## History and Development

Diffusion models were introduced in 2015 as a method to train a model that can sample from a highly complex probability distribution. They used techniques from non-equilibrium thermodynamics, especially diffusion.(no content)A 2020 paper proposed the Denoising Diffusion Probabilistic Model (DDPM), which improves upon the previous method by variational inference.

## Applications

As of 2024, diffusion models are mainly used for computer vision tasks, including image denoising, inpainting, super-resolution, image generation, and video generation.(no content)Other than computer vision, diffusion models have also found applications in natural language processing such as text generation and summarization, sound generation, and reinforcement learning.

## Notable Examples

Diffusion-based image generators have seen widespread commercial interest, such as Stable Diffusion and DALL-E.

Links: [{"title":"Diffusion model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diffusion_model"},{"title":"Bass diffusion model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bass_diffusion_model"},{"title":"Latent diffusion model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latent_diffusion_model"},{"title":"Stable Diffusion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stable_Diffusion"},{"title":"Text-to-image model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Text-to-image_model"},{"title":"Demic diffusion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Demic_diffusion"},{"title":"NovelAI - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NovelAI"},{"title":"Foundation model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Foundation_model"},{"title":"DALL-E - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DALL-E"},{"title":"Midjourney - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Midjourney"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about diffusion models:

## Overview

In machine learning, diffusion models, also known as diffusion-based generative models or score-based generative models, are a class of latent variable generative models.(no content)A diffusion model models data as generated by a diffusion process, whereby a new datum performs a random walk with drift through the space of all possible data.

## How They Work

A diffusion model consists of two major components: the forward diffusion process, and the reverse sampling process.(no content)The goal of diffusion models is to learn a diffusion process for a given dataset, such that the process can generate new elements that are distributed similarly as the original dataset.

## History and Development

Diffusion models were introduced in 2015 as a method to train a model that can sample from a highly complex probability distribution. They used techniques from non-equilibrium thermodynamics, especially diffusion.(no content)A 2020 paper proposed the Denoising Diffusion Probabilistic Model (DDPM), which improves upon the previous method by variational inference.

## Applications

As of 2024, diffusion models are mainly used for computer vision tasks, including image denoising, inpainting, super-resolution, image generation, and video generation.(no content)Other than computer vision, diffusion models have also found applications in natural language processing such as text generation and summarization, sound generation, and reinforcement learning.

## Notable Examples

Diffusion-based image generators have seen widespread commercial interest, such as Stable Diffusion and DALL-E.

Web search results for query: "Autonomous vehicle safety"

Links: [{"title":"Advanced driver-assistance system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Advanced_driver-assistance_system"},{"title":"Zoox - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zoox"},{"title":"Self-driving car - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-driving_car"},{"title":"Death of Elaine Herzberg - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Death_of_Elaine_Herzberg"},{"title":"Automated mining - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automated_mining"},{"title":"Velodyne Lidar - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Velodyne_Lidar"},{"title":"Operational design domain - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Operational_design_domain"},{"title":"Intelligent transportation system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intelligent_vehicle_technologies"},{"title":"Aurora Innovation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aurora_Innovation"},{"title":"VaMP - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/VaMP"}]

I've completed the web search for "Autonomous vehicle safety." Here's a summary of the key findings:

## Key Safety Technologies and Approaches

Advanced Driver-Assistance Systems (ADAS) use automated technology, such as sensors and cameras, to detect nearby obstacles or driver errors and respond accordingly.(no content)ADAS is proven to reduce road fatalities by minimizing human error.(no content)Artificial intelligence (AI) plays a pivotal role in the development and operation of autonomous vehicles (AVs), enabling them to perceive their surroundings, make decisions, and navigate safely without human intervention.

## Operational Safety Limitations

Operational design domain (ODD) is a term for a particular operating context for an autonomous system, with context defined by environmental, geographical, and time-of-day conditions. Manufacturers use ODD to indicate where/how their product operates safely.

## Real-World Safety Concerns

The search results also highlight important safety challenges. Consumers will avoid autonomous vehicles unless they trust them as safe, and robotaxis operating in San Francisco received pushback over perceived safety risks.(no content)As of November 17, 2025, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) has logged 111 accidents involving Zoox vehicles in autonomous mode, of which a small number resulted in injury or property damage.

The results indicate that while autonomous vehicle technology offers significant safety improvements through automation, ongoing testing, regulation, and building public trust remain critical challenges for wider adoption.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [completed] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [completed] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

Perfect! I have successfully completed the analysis of the DiffScene paper. Here's a summary of what was done:

## Analysis Summary

**Paper Classification:** Contribution

**Key Triples Extracted:**

1. **Diffusion model** (method - uses)
   - Core technique leveraged for generating safety-critical scenarios

2. **Self-driving car** (task - uses)
   - The primary domain and application area for the scenario generation method

3. **Adversarial machine learning** (concept - uses)
   - Used to guide the diffusion generation through adversarial optimization objectives

4. **Scenario planning** (method - proposes)
   - The paper proposes a novel diffusion-based approach to automatically generate realistic safety-critical scenarios

**Validation Result:** ✅ All checks passed successfully!

All Wikipedia URLs have been verified, and the JSON structure meets all requirements including:
- At least 1 "uses" relation (papers build on existing work) ✓
- At least 1 "proposes" relation (contribution papers must create something new) ✓

- [Adversarial machine learning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adversarial_machine_learning)
